topics.title: Introduction
topics.summary: Statistical simulation refers to the use of random sampling techniques to model and analyze complex systems or stochastic processes. It helps approximate results that are otherwise difficult to compute analytically.

topics.title: Motivation
topics.summary: Analytical solutions to real‑world problems are often infeasible due to their mathematical complexity. Statistical simulation allows us to understand uncertainty, test hypotheses, and evaluate the performance of statistical estimators.

subtopics.title: Random number generation using probability distributions
subtopics.narration: Statistical simulation begins with generating random numbers that follow specified probability distributions.

subtopics.title: Sampling from populations or theoretical distributions
subtopics.narration: It involves drawing samples either from actual populations or from theoretical distribution models.

subtopics.title: Repeated trials to approximate expected values
subtopics.narration: By conducting many repeated trials, the simulation approximates expected values of interest.

subtopics.title: Using simulation outcomes for inference and prediction
subtopics.narration: The results of the simulation are then used for statistical inference and making predictions.

subtopics.title: Example
subtopics.narration: Estimation of π using random points inside a unit square. Steps: 1. Generate N random points (x, y) in [0,1] × [0,1]. 2. Count how many fall inside the unit circle (x² + y² < 1). 3. Estimate π as 4 × (points inside circle) / N.

subtopics.title: Python Example
subtopics.narration: ```python import numpy as np N = 1000000 x = np.random.rand(N) y = np.random.rand(N) pi_est = 4 * np.sum(x**2 + y**2 <= 1) / N print("Estimated π:", pi_est) ``` This code generates one million random points, checks which lie inside the unit circle, and computes an estimate of π.

subtopics.title: Provides flexibility for complex problems
subtopics.narration: Simulation can be adapted to a wide range of intricate scenarios where analytical methods fail.

subtopics.title: Simplifies uncertainty quantification
subtopics.narration: Random sampling makes it straightforward to assess variability and uncertainty.

subtopics.title: Enables visual understanding of stochastic processes
subtopics.narration: Simulated data can be plotted to illustrate the behavior of random systems.

subtopics.title: Applicable across science, finance, and AI
subtopics.narration: The techniques are useful in many disciplines, from natural sciences to financial modeling and artificial intelligence.

subtopics.title: Example
subtopics.narration: Estimating confidence interval for mean. Steps: 1. Draw B bootstrap samples (with replacement) from data. 2. Compute the mean for each sample. 3. Use the distribution of means to estimate standard error and confidence intervals.

subtopics.title: Python Example
subtopics.narration: ```python import numpy as np data = np.array([12, 7, 9, 15, 11, 8, 10]) B = 1000 means = [np.mean(np.random.choice(data, size=len(data), replace=True)) for _ in range(B)] conf_interval = (np.percentile(means, 2.5), np.percentile(means, 97.5)) print("95% CI for mean:", conf_interval) ``` The script creates 1,000 bootstrap samples, calculates their means, and derives a 95 % confidence interval for the population mean.

subtopics.title: Can be computationally intensive
subtopics.narration: Large numbers of iterations may require substantial computing resources.

subtopics.title: Accuracy depends on number of iterations
subtopics.narration: More simulation runs generally lead to more precise estimates.

subtopics.title: Random number quality affects results
subtopics.narration: Poor pseudo‑random number generators can bias the outcomes.

topics.title: Summary
topics.summary: Statistical simulation is a powerful tool for approximating complex models using random sampling. Monte Carlo methods and bootstrapping are foundational techniques that provide insights into uncertainty and sampling behavior.
